intro: Lophiolepis richteriana, commonly known as the Richter's lichen, is a type of crustose lichen that forms a thin, tightly adhering layer on rock surfaces. It belongs to the family Lecanoraceae and is characterized by its pale yellow to orange thallus with distinct, elongated lobes. The lichen is composed of a symbiotic association between a photosynthetic alga and a fungal partner, which allows it to thrive in harsh, arid environments. It is commonly found in rocky, sunny habitats across southern Africa, including Namibia and South Africa. This species is of interest to botanists and ecologists due to its role in soil stabilization and its sensitivity to environmental changes.
